bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, October 25, 1952

div1.p: Hench generally approves of the selection of names to be honored on a plaque at the dedication of Camp Lazear. He asks to have a phrase clarified from Nogueira's last letter concerning the qualifications necessary to receive the Finlay Award.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, October 25, 1952
div1.opener:
October 25, 1952
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Havana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
I am greatly disturbed that I have not been able to answer your letter sooner.
I have been out of town a great deal recently.

First of all, let me give you my general approval of the decisions which you
and your colleagues made. I personally would have liked to have seen at least
Dean, Case XY, and perhaps Pinto, included even though they were not at Camp
Lazear. I realize you have to draw a line somewhere and if you are confining
the honors to the soldiers who served at Camp Lazear, these two men naturally
will not be in.

You mention Albarez. That should be the No. 40 Alvarez, not the No. 2 Alvarez,
listed in my alphabetical list on page 8 of my memorandum of July 21, 1952 to
you. I don't believe we know his first name.

You misspelled two names in your letter. It is Hanberry, not Handberry and
Sternberg, not Sternberg. I am sure these were merely typographical errors.

As to the exclusion of Stark, I suppose you are probably right. His contri-
butions were much more in the line of duty whereas Ames' contributions,
though essentially in line of duty were done so attentively and were so im-
portant that they can be classified as being rather “beyond the line of duty.”

I am not sure what you mean when you ask me to tell you who I believe “ought
to be decorated with Finlay's to the Board.” Perhaps you are suggesting that
I nominate some men for the Finlay condecoration. Unfortunately I do not know
the qualifications for these nominations. I did not receive any information along
this line. Nor does your letter specify whether these nominations pertain to
yellow fever personalities or to American doctors or to other distinguished
Americans who might be visiting Cuba on December 3. If you are confining the
matter to yellow fever personalities and if you must confine it to doctors, it
seems to me the two outstanding nominees would be Doctor Cooke, one of the
volunteers, and General Truby; the latter not so much because of his actual
service in the yellow fever experiments, but because of his life-long interest
in Cuba and his military service in its behalf. If non-medical men are eligible
and I believe they are ad Johnny Moran was honored, I think Hanberry should be
honored. After all, he and Cooke are the only two left.

If non-yellow fever personalities are to be honored, General Streit, head of
the Walter Reed Hospital, who will attend the ceremony if invited, might well
be honored although of course perhaps the honor should go to his chief, The
Surgeon General, but that is not for me to decide and of course General Walter
Lawrence Reed is certainly worthy of such an honor not only because of his life-
long service to the American Army (he was Inspector General) but, from the
Cuban standpoint, because he served as a young private and then a lieutenant
in Cuba in the Spanish-American War; in fact he received his commission as a
lieutenant while in Cuba.

If you want other types of nominations from me, please let me know what you
had in mind; that is, what category of men.

I shall certainly try to come to the dedication. I wonder if your secretary
would make a tentative reservation for me at the Hotel Nacional? If I come,
I can only stay two days, probably December 2 and 3. I will have to fly as
I only have four days left of my allotted time for the entire year.

I hope you received my letter and wire about preserving any wood that you
have to remove from Building No. 1. I would certainly like to have some
with which to make souvenirs.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
